description.narrative: Management Plan
This is a management project which contains UN system coordination output for office oversight, management and operations support.
capital of a political entity
The project aims to increase climate change resilience at landscape level by applying the principles of ecosystem based adaptation.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which climate finance is being accessed (by government and non-government institutions)
Extent to which there is a strengthened system in place to access, deliver, monitor, report on and verify climate finance
Extent to which implementation of comprehensive measures - plans, strategies, policies, programmes and budgets - to achieve low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives has improved.

The project objective is to maintain the water provisioning services supplied by mountain and steppe ecosystems by internalizing climate change risks within land and water resource management regimes.
drainage basin

1. Number of eco-regional EBA strategy programs and action plans adopted by National and Aimag Governments 2. Decrease in average Rural Poverty rate within the target watershed population. 3. Number of Soums replicating EBA principles and practices within the target eco-regions

comment.narrative: 1. No single Aimag governments have eco-regional EBA strategy programs and action plans adopted by National and Aimag Governments 2. Rural Poverty rate are 0.433 in Ulz basin and 0.495 in Kharkhiraa/Turgen basin. 3. No Soums apply EBA principles and practices within the target eco-regions.
1. pasture rotation and other ecosystem based grazing practices piloted 2. pasture land management is improved in the target areas

With 40% of Mongolia’s people dependent on herding for their income, healthy natural ecosystems are critical to sustain livelihoods. 17 districts initiated pasture rotation and other ecosystem based grazing practices in their territory, such as pasture irrigation through spring protection, well rehabilitation and established water harvesting structures. The total area with improved pasture land management amounts to 110,000 ha in Kharkhiraa, Turgen and 976,000 ha Ulz river basin.

1. Institutional structure/system for ecosystem based adaptation established. 2. Adaptation approaches and techniques adopted maintaining ecosystem integrity and water security under conditions of climate change.

1. Institutional and local capacities for Ecosystem-based Adaptation and Integrated Water Resources Management is strengthened in Uvs lake and Tes river basin in the Altai Mountain and Ulz river basin in the Mongolian Daurian Steppe eco-regions. Institutional structure for river basin management integrating climate change risks (Administration and Council its supporting local communities as a Water users associations) established and operational in target areas as model for replication. 2. Series of innovative approaches on Economic evaluations to compare the landscape level costs and benefits of EBA approaches produced, its recommendations on 6 sectors (water, forest, wildlife, land use, climate and husbandry) disseminated to relevant stakeholders to include its policy and planning and tested at the Target ecoregions as pilot adaptation measures. - Suite of physical techniques to improve ecosystem resilience established in two critical watersheds. - EbA and IWRM principles are reflected into target aimag/soum sectors planning and implementation. Benefits and advantages of pilot adaptation technologies that are cost effective and environmental friendly are replicated in outside of target areas.

title.narrative: Disaster risk reduction at the local level

description.narrative: Strengthening local level capacities for disaster risk reduction, management and coordination in Mongolia.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Total number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM)
Number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM) that are effective
The goal of the project is to facilitate a decentralized disaster management through sustainable prevention, response, and coordination mechanisms.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator 1. Level of progress towards establishing policy and regulatory frameworks to enable clear roles and responsibilities to support Disaster reduction management at the local level. It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0. Roles and responsibilities unclear; Law on disaster needs changes Scale#1. Policy recommendations formulated and management mechanisms identified Scale#2. Action plan, recommendations and management mechanisms are validated through relevant stakeholders Scale#3. Law on Disaster reflects required changes to support the disaster risk management at th local level and implementation rolled out
Indicator 2. Extent of efforts made in strengthening the competencies and procedures tailored for local level disaster management mechanisms Scale#0. Low human, technical and financial capacities at the local level for effective preparedness and response to disasters. No formal body for disaster management at the soum and community level Scale#1. Capacity needs determined and validated. Awareness raised on hazards, vulnerabilities and responses measures (a detailed set of indicators for this scale is found in the project RRF such as sampling survey and # of media programmes and training materials disseminated; # of vulnerability and multi-hazard maps for city, district, aimag and soum level). Scale#2. Resource mobilization and material acquisition plan (focus on aimag and soum level emergency units) supported and trainings rolled out (detailed set of indicators for this scale is in the RRF such as # of methodologies and software for maintenance and exchange of disaster related information; % of increase in material acquisition of aimag and district EMDs, self-help groups and task forces); Scale#3. Operational DRR professional teams and task forces successfully respond to emergencies making use of a volunteer support and priority actions stated in the national disaster policy and programme. (see RRF for detailed list)

description.narrative:
Indicator 1. Existence of a comprehensive review of the state building, conducted through consultative processes and formulation of the recommendations for institutional reforms. Scale: Yes/No.
Indicator 2. Extent of the consultative policy support for state structuring and legislative drafting
It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0. No standard process for legal drafting Scale#1. Procedural standards available for legal drafting, which is formulated based on the policy studies . Scale#2. Law on Legislative drafting is approved after stakeholder dialogues Scale#3. Legal implementation and drafting procedures are monitored and the proposals for institutional reform/state structuring are developed
Indicator 3.Scope/extent of the improved relationship between parliament and citizens
It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0.Little awareness and use of the Right to Information Law and restricted access for citizens to parliament. Scale#1. Recommendations formulated for citizen's access to parliament based on the study and public relations strategy developed for parliament outreach Scale#2. A public relations strategy is developed as part of improving parliamentary outreach; Scale#3. Recommended action for improving citizen's accessapproved and the implementation rolled out

Output 1. 1.1. A study on performance of the Constitution 1992 is updated reflecting changes in the past 3 years. Output 2. 2.1. Training on guidelines of the Law on Legislation and the Law on General Administrative Procedures conducted, and the guidelines are piloted on selected draft laws. 2.2. A book "Law drafting techniques" translated. Output 3. 3.1. Proposals for the revision of the Law on Information Transparency and Right to Information prepared. Output 4. 4.1. Review of the implementation of Chapter II and V of UNCAC conducted and submitted.

Output 1. 1.1. An updated study on performance of the Constitution 1992 was conducted, reflecting changes in the past 3 years, with added chapters on national sovereignty and local self-governance. Output 2. 2.1. Training on guidelines of the Law on Legislation and the Law on General Administrative Procedures conducted for staff of the Parliament Secretariat and the organizations reporting to the Parliament. The guidelines were piloted on selected draft laws. 2.2. A book "Law drafting techniques" translated. Output 3. 3.1. Proposals for the revision of the Law on Information Transparency and Right to Information prepared. Output 4. 4.1. Review of the implementation of Chapter II and V of UNCAC conducted and submitted.
The project is operationally closed

comment.narrative: Total LPA without community managed areas is 16 Mln ha but not included in the NPA System
192 Mln ha

Total LPA without community managed areas was found to be 205 million ha based on the recent indepth survey on the LPA coverage Although it appears that the end of project target has already been reached this new figure is largely as a result of more accurate investigation on the LPA coverage which tends to be fluid as local authority can gazette and degazette or the set period for protection can expire 205 million ha includes 3 new LPAs and extension of Gulzat LPA which were facilitate directly by the project accounting for 025 million ha in total However LPA are not yet recognized as part of the national PA system With the approval of the revised SPA Law in the current version the LPAs will be officially part of the PA system

30 community groups of which 15 newly established with total area of 340000 ha officially recognized and contracted with the soum governor for taking management responsibility over land and biodiversity in target 3 LPAs By March 2015 a total of 1629 community conservation areas 82 mln hectare are recorded throughout the country with user rights over forest wildlife water and pasture resources

description.narrative: Specific NPA legislation amended andor new regulation adopted to establish and guide effective management of community conservation areas

comment.narrative: 0 No national law andor regulation adopted as described
1 national law andor regulation adopted as described

1Regulation on Taking land under local protection 2000 is currently under revision towards setting up clear criteria and processes for LPAs including CCAs
2As a result of 1st National Forum for CBOs organized by MEGDT jointly with all donor organizations its been issued an Order 07 of Parliament Standing Committee on Agriculture and Environment dated July 09 2015 towards undertaking required actions and allocation of state budget to strengthen the governance and management of CCAs and build capacity of CBOs throughout the country
3Working group for drafting revised laws of Special Protected Area and Buffer Zone was re established due to recently restructured Ministry of Environment Green Development Tourism MEGDT The working group has refined the revised drafts through series of meetings
The following key issues reflected to the revised draft SPA Law in relation to CCA
Local protected areas are part of the national protected areas network
In addition to government its proposed collaborative and community management governance types for both state and local protected areas
4A comprehensive feasibility study on current legal framework for community conservation areas and proposal of revisionsamendments to key legislations including Law on Special Protected Areas Environmental Protection Law and Law on Land The study result has given practical basis to legitimize the community conservation areas to become an effective part of Mongolias National protected areas system and allowing for communitybased conservation management

description.narrative: The International Think Tank for Land Locked Developing Countries (ITT LLDCs) is aimed at providing support for strategic interventions to enhance the development prospects of all LLDCs.

title.narrative: LLDC Project document_revised_15 Jan14_ FINAL _with signatures
Research Study on Economic Diversification of LLDCs

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Total number of inter-regional SS&TC partnerships
Number of inter-regional SS&TC partnerships delivering measurable and sustainable development benefits for participants
Existence of legal, regulatory and/or policy frameworks for SS&TC
existence of an institutional focal point within government for SS&TC

The International Think Tank is aimed at providing support for strategic interventions to enhance the development prospects of all LLDCs. It is a platform for knowledge sharing, support for intra LLDC collaboration and other South-South engagement.
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative:
Baseline established in 2014 (prodoc).
Indicator 1- Scale #0. ITT is not operational Indicator 2: 0 (no studies)

Indicator 1. - Interim ITT is fully operational and the legal framework for ITT is drafted Indicator 2: - Two more studies conducted
Additional narrative on the action: 1. Draft Charter including the modus operandi shared with LLDCs group for discussion and endorsement; 2. At least two more countries have acceded 3. Research papers are delivered and promoted at local as well as at international events 4. Research papers are available in Mongolian language

• As of today, 6 countries (Mongolia, Laos, Armenia, Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, and Burkina Faso) have ratified the Multilateral Agreement and 3 (Niger, Ethiopia, Paraguay) have signed the agreement and are in the process of ratification. * The Modus Operandi / Statute of ITT has been shared with the LLDC Group at the UN in New York through the Mongolian Permanent Mission for the review and approval of the LLDC Group.
• The joint letter by Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Mongolia and UN-ESCAP has been sent out to LLDC Governments in Asia Pacific region calling on each country to accede to the Multilateral Agreement on the establishment of an ITT at their earliest convenience.
• The joint letter by Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Mongolia, UNDP and UN-OHRLLS has been sent out to LLDC Governments calling on each country to accede to the Multilateral Agreement on the establishment of an ITT at their earliest convenience.
• The ITT has carried out a field trip to Lao PDR for conducting a comparative study on "Strengthening emergency and essential surgical care at selected rural hospitals in Laos" in cooperation with the Collaborating Center of the World Health Organization between 8-10 March.
• The National workshop on mainstreaming the Vienna Programme of Action was organized by the ITT in association with the MFA of Mongolia and UN Office of the High Representative for the Least Developed Countries, Landlocked Developing Countries and Small Island Developing Countries (OHRLLS) in Ulaanbaatar on 27-28 April.
• The ITT participated in the 49th Annual Governors Meeting of the ADB for the second time in a row since ITT was granted the OBSERVER Status in 2015 on 2-6 May in Frankfurt.
• The ITT conducted a research on “Sea access for a landlocked developing countries: Case India – Nepal” and launched the draft report of the study in association with the Austrian Embassy in Ulaanbaatar on 9 June.
• On the invitation of the Under-Secretary General and High Representative

Indicator 1. - 3 more countries to accede to the multilateral agreement. ITT is a full-pledged international organization and fully operational. Indicator 2: - Three researches done on connectivity and trade facilitation

Targets achieved
1. ITT is a full -pledged international organization with 10 LLDCs' ratification and fully operational. 2. Three researches conducted and discussed/presented through several public occasions including the international conference "Exploring connectivity in Landlocked Developing Countries" in April.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which the Parliament has improved its administrative and human resources capacities required to discharge its mandates in relation to law-making, oversight and representation
It aims to provide fast support for upstream policy innovation and scaling up activities.
capital of a political entity

The existing mechanisms for conducting upstream policy and innovation activities were reviewed, and new approaches to achieve the above objectives were explored including defining a new project type and streamlining existing delivery mechanisms. The result of this analysis concluded that the recommended approach is to combine the DAS and DSS delivery mechanisms into one rapid response facility for upstream policy and innovation results (renamed the “Engagement Facility”) and to revisit the procedures and guidelines around the use of this facility to encourage a greater potential for policy impact.

comment.narrative: The Government of Mongolia and the United Nations Development Programme have developed the UNDP Country Programme Action Plan (CPAP) for 2012-2016 on the basis of long standing cooperation between the Government and UNDP in effectively supporting Mongolia's development. description.narrative: Stakeholder engagement mechanisms in place for accountable, transparent and equitable decision making. Mongolia has the National REDD+ Strategy with clear institutional arrangements to implement results-based actions. National or sub-national FREL/FRL drafted and endorsed NFMS developed and functional as a MRV system for REDD+

comment.narrative: National REDD+ Strategy is not available for Mongolia to receive results-based payments for carbon stored in the forest.
1. Project management unit established and operational. 2. UNREDD key studies started. Stakeholders engagement supported.
1. Project management unit established and operational. 2. UNREDD key studies started. Stakeholders engagement supported.

- Additional National Forests Inventory plots conducted - additional National Forest Inventory for degraded forest. - Biennial Update Report supported, - National financial mechanisms and taxation were reviewed.

Achieved. Additional National Forests Inventory plots were undertaken in order to determine carbon stocks in degraded forest, and secondly, the country's greenhouse gas emission reporting process was supported through technical advice on the preparation of the Biennial Update Report, and thirdly, national financial mechanisms, taxation, levies and proposals that may be available for future leveraging for climate change and forest management as part of the National REDD+ Strategy were reviewed. Mongolia has completed the additional National Forest Inventory for degraded forest.

capital of a political entity
Alignment of subnational plans, M&E frameworks and budgets with SDV and SDcs in the UB City supported

comment.narrative: In February 2016 Mongolia's parliament approved the 'Sustainable Development Vision 2030' (SDV). This vision is anchored in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and seeks to address the development challenges. While the SDV already reflects many of the SDGs, gaps remain and policy coherence and trade-offs will need to be considered when deciding upon priorities and for developing medium and short-term plans and policies. Similarly financing options will need to be explored.
1. MOU with UB city signed 2. Project implementation support function set and operational
